title: 108_hr4313
content: The "Antibullying Campaign Act of 2004" may be cited as such. Grants are provided for antiharassment programs. The Secretary of Education provides grants to States for antiharassment programs in public schools, prohibiting harassment based on various factors. States must submit detailed applications to receive grants. The Secretary of Education requires detailed applications from States for antiharassment programs in public schools, including information on prohibition of harassment, definitions, and budget allocation. The Secretary reviews and approves or disapproves applications within 30 days. The Secretary of Education requires detailed applications from States for antiharassment programs in public schools. Approval or disapproval of the application must be done within 30 days. States must provide matching funds of at least 50% from non-Federal sources to receive the grant for the antiharassment program. SEC. 3. STUDY AND REPORT. The Secretary of Education will conduct a study on harassment in public schools, including the number of students harassed, demographics, types of harassment, states with anti-harassment campaigns, and state funding for such programs. A report with findings will be submitted to Congress annually for three years. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress containing the findings and analysis of the study on harassment in public schools. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines "harassment" as creating a hostile environment through conduct or verbal threats, and "school" as an elementary or secondary school. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education, and "State" includes various territories. Authorization of Appropriations: $75,000,000 authorized annually for fiscal years 2005-2008 to carry out the Act, funds available until September 30, 2008.
